awd_titl_txt: The dynamic interaction between a hypersonic flow and a flexible panel
awd_abstract_narration:
A major challenge in hypersonic flight is the presence of large aerodynamic forces and high heating rates that combine to cause dynamic deformation and thermal-induced buckling of aircraft structures. The interaction between a shock wave and the boundary layer can cause high heating, vibrations and structural instabilities such as flutter. These effects can lead to fatigue of thin panel structures with potentially catastrophic implications for a flight vehicle. To address these issues, this project will investigate the flow near a compliant panel under hypersonic conditions.  It will also lead to an educational partnership between University of Texas-Austin and Huston-Tillotson University - small private historically black university.

The goal of the proposed work is to investigate the interaction between a thin compliant panel underneath hypersonic separated flows which are generated by single- and double-sharp fins at an angle of attack. Combined kilo Hertz-rate optical diagnostics will be used to make simultaneous measurements of the panel displacement, surface pressures, and near-wall velocity fields. A range of panel thicknesses will be used to vary the vibrational frequencies and amplitudes. An important innovation will be the use a new inverse method to compute the fluctuating pressure field that causes the dynamic deformation. Tailoring the elastic and inertial properties of the panels will enable the investigation of passive control of the separated flow unsteadiness and, thus, potentially reduce the deleterious effects of the separated flow by purposeful design. The educational plan will focus on a robust effort to engage under-represented minority undergraduate students in the research.

The project is co-funded by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The major objective of this project is to investigate the fluid-structure interaction of a compliant panel exposed to supersonic and hypersonic shock-induced turbulent separation. Understanding fluid-structure interaction is important for designing supersonic/hypersonic aircraft for which structural vibration does not lead to fatigue and failure. Specifically, we aimed to understand how shock/boundary layer interaction (SBLI) unsteadiness excites the structural dynamics of a compliant panel, and in turn, how the panel vibration affects the flow. This work was primarily experimental and was conducted at Mach numbers of 2 and 5. For diagnostic methods, we used 5 kHz stereo digital image correlation (DIC), 20 kHz pressure sensitive paint (PSP) and 50 kHz particle image velocimetry (PIV) to obtain information about the panel deformation, compliant wall surface pressure and flow velocity field, respectively.  

Significant Results

1. An important result of this work is that the presence of both the Mach 2 boundary layer and the SBLI caused a significant skew in the structural mode shapes, which agreed with theoretical predictions using classical piston theory. Interestingly, there was little difference in the mode shapes for the boundary-layer-only forcing as compared to the SBLI-forcing, despite the SBLI causing significantly higher amplitude of deformation.

2. The oscillation of the panel strongly influenced the fluid dynamics of both the boundary layer alone and in the presence of the SBLI. With SBLI, the panel motion directly influenced the separation shock foot motion, effectively coupling to the first panel vibration mode frequency. However, lack of change in the structural vibration mode-shapes indicates that the presence of the SBLI at Mach 2 did not lead to significant two-way coupling.

3. In contrast to the Mach 2 case, at Mach 5 the panel exhibited only weak vibratory response in the presence of the boundary layer alone (no SBLI). On the other hand, the presence of the SBLI introduced a significant amount of forcing, leading to large non-linear vibrations on the order of the panel thickness. This behavior is very different to that observed at Mach 2. It was further shown that the surface pressure fluctuations at Mach 5 increased by about 50% in one case due to the panel compliance.

4. We also investigated the use of tailored stiffness to see if we could modify the structural response of the panel. The idea is that it may be possible to add small structural elements to a thin panel to substantially change its dynamic response. This was investigated by attaching thin ribs of material near the location of the separation shock impingement. In one case the rib modified both the stiffness and mass of the system, and in the other the rib caused an increase in mass and damping, but not in stiffness. Results showed that especially the latter configuration was effective at reducing the vibrations of the system by 50%.

5. The examination of the rigid panel cases (non-compliant) provided new insight into the low-frequency dynamics of SBLI at both Mach 2 and Mach 5. Three different SBLIs were studied, a weak interaction at Mach 2, and a weak and stronger interaction at Mach 5. The different cases resulted in different shock strength and separation length scales. The different interactions shared many similarities, such as a strong correlation between the separation shock foot and reattachment region, which reflects the breathing motion that is well-established in the literature. However, the Mach 2 SBLI showed a stronger correlation between pressure fluctuations in the upstream boundary layer and the separated flow unsteadiness. The Mach 5 cases showed virtually no correlation of the upstream fluctuations and downstream flow.  

6. The project provided full or partial support for two PhD students and one post-doctoral fellow. The students and post doc gained excellent training in experimental high-speed aerodynamics, structural dynamics, and the application of optical diagnostic methods. Both students and the post doc were sent to several scientific conferences that enabled them to present their research, learn about others' research, and network with others in the field. 

7. The co-PIs have engaged in outreach activities to reach a diverse pool of students and introduce them to hypersonic flow research. For three summers, we hosted a Hispanic undergraduate student or woman student as interns. The students were trained in using Matlab, CAD software, and conducting measurements in a laboratory environment. Furthermore, we fostered a new relationship between UT Austin and Huston Tillotson University, which is an HBCU. This effort led to the development of a combined course/internship relationship that enabled three different Huston Tillotson students do research at UT Austin.

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2024
Modified by: Noel T Clemens
